title: How to find a job with my associate degree - Quora
tags: Job Search Advice for College Graduates

response.answer_text: With the RIGHT associate’s degree you can get a full time job with benefits making $25/hour. “Unfortunately” this is going to require that you spend two years in school at a total cost of $10,000. For example the CC close to my home in the suburbs has a robotics program. Many of the classes are free—government grants. The class size is 3–4 students. (All the “smart kids” are taking The History of Rock and Roll at a four year college downtown. Their job expectation is making lattes.) I forgot the good part. Many of the prospective employers have a tuition benefit. You could complete your bachelor’s degree for free. This is not glamorous. There is no football team. It is definitely not cool. It is just low risk and affordable. BUT three or four years from now you will be driving in your (used) Lexis with your hot girlfriend to the airport to fly to the College National Championship game at some warm location. Your old high school buddies will be working at a part time job at Dick’s Sporting Goods for $8.50/hour trying to figure out how to pay off their student loans. (You don’t like robots? I have a better opportunity at a CC in northern Kentucky.) The idea that you need a degree from a four year college to get a decent job is a &&^%* myth. There is a HUGE mismatch between the skills obtained at a four year college and the skills required at many of the well-paying jobs available in today’s economy. CC’s are filling that gap.

It depends on which industry you're going into and how big your ambitions are. If you have excellent transferable skills (e.g. communication [written and verbal], relationship management, attention to detail, etc.), you could land a “good” entry-level job. If you want stability and just want to stay in the same spot, you can work hard to get incremental salary increases or move into a better paying position afterward a longer period of time. You'd be considered a strong & steady performer, but staying in an entry-level role for more than 4+ years would raise some eyebrows if you ever become unemployed. If you are looking to get a leadership role in the future, an associate’s degree will not suffice in most companies…unless you’re an anomaly like the 20/30-something year olds running billion dollar companies. However, if you are fortunate, you could complete an associate’s degree and then find a job at a company with excellent benefits who can pay for you to complete another degree. If the cost of education means you can really only afford a 2-year degree, spend those years wisely and build your network, whether that be speaking to your professors regularly and asking them to introduce you to people in the industry, building a strong LinkedIn profile and meeting people you admire for coffee, etc. P.S. If your communication and relationship skills aren't very good, you will REALLY need to figure that out and hone those to succeed in the long run. Good luck :)

To be honest, in today’s job market, it doesn’t help a lot. James made a great point in that if you get an associate’s in a technical field, you do have a better chance. For a lot of jobs, a master’s is the new bachelor’s. I have two associates, a bachelors and a masters and the student loans to prove every step of the way. But even with a masters it’s hard to get jobs. The biggest paradox is of course the experience paradox. Where you can’t get a job without an experience and you can’t get experience without a job. If you’re not getting an associates in a technical field, then you need to focus on a bachelors. I would suggest, if you can afford it, doing some unpaid internships in your desired field. That will help you get your some experience but also a deeper understanding of the necessary qualifications for that field. BUT and there is always a BUT, you should also just ignore me and anyone else and just apply for jobs. You might find a great gig with your associates. You won’t know until you try. Just be sure to have a backup for if it doesn’t work.

They are many positions that require only an associate’s degree. Most technical jobs only require a two year degree (drafter, maintenance tech, many medical technician jobs). Note I consider an AAS degree to be the equivalent if “trade school” for the sake of the discussion.The benefit of an AAS is you still can continue to get a four-year degree at some point, if you so chose. But if you plan to transfer sooner than later, a full AS degree is better.You can also get business-related degrees. Some pay as well as four-year degrees (English majors don't get paid as well as many people who work in a skilled trade). Here are some related answers that went into some detail on the advantages and benefits of an AS degree. Is an associate's degree in engineering worth anything?Should trade schools be promoted as much as four year colleges?Why is community college stigmatized? My parents’ friends, who are decent people, think I'm a failure for attending community college. What's honestly wrong with community college?

From my experience, not really. There has to be demand for it ontop of being in your locale. I recieved an AA in Liberal Arts but that’s glorified high school. I recieved an AS in business requires at least an BS. Maybe an MBA. Working on an AAS in electronics, but it has a 2% job growth out until 2028. Anything is possible, but it’s unlikely. I’m sorta stuck at the moment. My interests aren’t in demand, and especially at my level of education. It’s a lot cheaper than University though.

It really depends on the field. My son just finished a two-year program in IT and is now getting as much money as I was with a Masters. Trade schools will get you well paying jobs. If your are looking into the medical fields, a 2 year Paramedic Program will start you out at around $27.00 p/H. You can get a 2 year RN degree, but many hospitals will require a B.S. The thing about the Associates, is that later on, if you want to continue your education, you have that as a foundation.

Generally speaking, the answer is yes! So lots of people have landed jobs, even good and well-paying ones, with just an Associates degree. FYI, I’ve had plenty of students do it! at the various places where I’ve taught. Many having no prior background or experience in what they were studying. Others having some experience or a background but lacking the degree itself. So yes, there are a ton of Associate degree holders and new graduates who’ve landed jobs because of it. But does that mean you’re qualified for job X? Maybe, maybe not. It all depends upon the job itself. So you may not qualify for certain things with just an Associates. Yet there are other things for which you will be qualified. Thus, there are plenty of jobs available to those with an Associates degree!

You have to define good job. There are many jobs open at the technician level for people with two year associates degree. Your path to promotion will depend upon your performance on the job. As you rise higher, you will compete with people who have four year degrees. But your experience will usually match their degree and you can remain competitive. The computer industry and biotechnology field are two areas where to your degrees are helpful for getting a job. Best of luck in your career. Pardon my typographical, spelling, and punctuation as i am using speech-to-text software.

Depends very much on the associate’s degree. There are some “technical” jobs, and some entry-level health care ones, where a specialized AA/AS will qualify you for a job, and where you can often get placement through the Junior/Community College’s career office. There’s also often a practical/internship-like component to them. In general, though, just like a BA, it will only partially qualify you for a job, and you will usually need to put more time in with internships and other unpaid or minimally paid work and/or find an employer willing to take a risk on someone “unproven.”

My own $0.02, YMMV: An ASN (Associate in Nursing), leading to licensure as an RN certainly does. Same for dental hygiene, associated health sciences, etc. Most AAS (Associate in Applied Sciences) generally offer very good job opportunities. Most academic AA or AS degrees barely move the needle. With those you really need to finish a BA/S to get the benefit.

Usually, no matter what kind of degree you have, you have to apply endlessly to many job postings until you land at least a call for an interview. I have a master's degree and so does my husband and when we need to find a new job, we keep sitting in front of a computer every single day of the week for several hours and send out applications to everyone we can. Sometimes we even forget the companies we had sent it out to and then one of them calls for an interview and we have to actually go and research what that company does. Out of about 50 applications, we would get about 3-4 calls for an interview. Of course, you need to read requirements for he job and then apply. It would be silly to apply for a job that requires at least a bachelor's with an associate degree and it would be equally silly to apply for a job that requires an associate in the posting with a master's degree :-)

I think an Associate Degree is good to get a starting job that pays $15 to $25/hour in the long run. However, in order to have a good future, you should plan on completing at a minimum a Bachelor’s degree in your subject and in the long-run, a Masters’ degree for a bright future. All the Best!

What is your career? You won’t be able to be a doctor or similar professional of any type. But if you are working retail it will probably help you get a mid-level managerial position, but not enough to be a store manager. An associate degree is a start, but more is better!

You can get a good Job without a degree. You don't really need to go to college to have a successful Job. Look at YouTubers. They make thousands or millions making videos. Or certain warehouses pay anywhere from 20 to 30 the hour. You could start your own dropshipping business or clothing store. Or become an Affiliate marketer like me and sell other peoples products

This is a nice question. So let begin. You know there is no limit to earn degree or knowledge. If learn more or if you give time for learning you will be able to a fulfil person on academic level. Remember one thing when your need to job if you haven't enough skill you won't be able to eligible person for this job. So make sure you have enough knowledge. If will better solution for you.

Any job you want in that field so you have associate degree but ask a open question Why did you waste your time studying the degree if you don't know what job you will have Crazy really crazy question.

That depends on what your career is. There are many well-paying careers that an associate’s degree can prepare you for. Not everyone needs to attend a four-year college, and with the cost of a four-year education these days, and the debt many have to incur to achieve one, it is a sensible alternative for someone whose interests and aptitudes align with one of the careers that an associate’s degree can prepare them to pursue.
It really depends on the job! You would likely be able to become a technician or assistant.
